entry.title: Re: Income Tax Depreciation in India
entry.content:
When you add a new depreciation area to an existing chart of depreciation, SAP doesn’t automatically populate values (acquisition, accumulated dep, etc.) in that area for existing assets.

As a result:

-During subsequent transactions (like retirement, transfer, or posting of depreciation), SAP tries to derive and adjust area values retroactively.
-This leads to duplicate postings (often “Retirement without revenue” appearing twice) because SAP attempts to catch up missing values in the new area and replicate existing area postings.

 

SectionDetails
Module / ComponentSAP S/4HANA Finance → Asset Accounting (FI-AA)
Business ScenarioCreated new depreciation area 15 for Income Tax Depreciation. For newly created assets, postings are fine. But for existing assets, when updating the depreciation key and performing retirement, system posts duplicate “Retirement without Revenue” entries in AW01N.
Issue ObservedTwo identical postings for retirement without revenue appear in AW01N with same amounts. GL and AA balances differ.
Root Cause1️⃣ New depreciation area 15 was added after existing assets were created, but its values (APC, accumulated depreciation, etc.) were not initialized.2️⃣ In Customizing (OADB), reference depreciation area not assigned or incorrectly configured.3️⃣ System tried to derive values dynamically during transaction posting, creating double postings.4️⃣ Program AFBN (Initialize Depreciation Area) was not executed after area creation.5️⃣ Area 15 possibly set to “Post to GL” unnecessarily, causing additional accounting entries.
Impact- Duplicate postings in FI-AA (double retirement lines)- Reconciliation mismatch between GL and AA- Incorrect accumulated depreciation values in area 15- Confusion in financial reporting and audit trail
Configuration / Customizing to CheckT-Code / Path:- OADB – Define Depreciation Areas → Verify area 15 setup- Ensure Reference Area = 01 (book depreciation area)- “Posting to GL” unchecked for Income Tax area (if not required)- Chart of Depreciation assigned correctly to company code (OXK3)- Verify Depreciation Key setup (AFAMA)
Resolution Steps1️⃣ Check and Correct Area Setup in OADB:• Reference area = 01• No real-time posting if not required.2️⃣ Run Program AFBN (Initialize Depreciation Area):• Enter Company Code and Area = 15• Test Run → then Update Run• System copies values from area 01 to 15 for existing assets.3️⃣ Verify Asset Master Data (AS03):• Ensure area 15 shows populated APC and depreciation values.4️⃣ Reverse Wrong Entries (AB08):• Reverse double postings from earlier retirements.5️⃣ Repost Retirement (ABAVN / ABAO):• Now system should post single “Retirement without revenue” entry.6️⃣ Run Depreciation Recalculation (AFAR):• Optional but ensures all planned depreciation values are recalculated.7️⃣ Reconcile GL & AA (ABST2 / FAAL):• Confirm zero balance difference.
Key Programs & Transactions- OADB → Define Depreciation Areas- AFBN → Initialize Depreciation Area for existing assets- AS03 → Display Asset Master Data- AB08 → Reverse Asset Document- ABAVN / ABAO → Retirement without Revenue- AFAR → Recalculate Depreciation- ABST2 / FAAL → Reconcile AA vs GL
Example – AFBN Execution ParametersCompany Code = 1000Depreciation Area = 15Reference Area = 01Chart of Depreciation = ZCORPTest Run = Yes (first)Update Run = Yes (after verification)Expected Log Message: “Depreciation area 15 initialized for existing assets – values copied from area 01.”
Validation After Fix- AW01N → Single retirement posting appears- AS03 → Area 15 values populated- AFAR → Planned depreciation aligned- ABST2 / FAAL → No reconciliation differences- FAGLL03 / FS10N → GL balances match AA values
SAP Notes / References- 199169 – AFBN: Initialize depreciation areas- 2177954 – Duplicate postings after adding new dep area- 188456 – How to initialize depreciation area- 307000 – AFAR/AFBN consistency programs guidance
Preventive Measures✅ Always execute AFBN immediately after creating a new depreciation area before performing any transaction.✅ Never enable “Post to GL” for non-ledger areas like Income Tax unless required.✅ Test configuration in a sandbox or QA system first.✅ Verify data consistency in AW01N after every major config change.✅ Document all area changes for audit trail.
Expected Final OutcomeAfter AFBN execution and reposting:• No duplicate lines in AW01N• Correct retirement postings• Fully reconciled AA and GL balances• Stable depreciation processing across all areas (01 and 15)

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: F0718 (Post General Journal Entries) with locked docu...
entry.content:
Hi @djwafelap ,

Below is a complete one-table summary explaining functional behavior, limitations, and all available configuration/authorization approaches.

 

SectionDetails / Explanation
Business requirement• Users with Role A → may change document type.• Users with Role B → must use pre-set document type, cannot change it.
App concernedF0718 – Post General Journal Entries (Fiori ID: F0718).
Default behaviour• The app reads defaults from a template or posting variant.• The “Read Only” checkbox for document type in templates is greyed out by design → cannot be activated manually.
Why “Read Only” cannot be ticked• In SAP standard Fiori design for F0718 templates, only certain header fields (e.g., Company Code, Posting Date) can be locked; document type is excluded because the system must allow override when copying templates.• This is a hard-coded UI restriction (SAP Note / KBA 3246069 and 3154605 mention similar template-field limits).
Direct workaround inside template❌ Not possible — “Read Only” flag is disabled by design and not extensible by in-app key user tools.
Alternative 1 – Authorization-based control (recommended)Use authorization object F_BKPF_BL → controls permitted document types per user/role.Steps:1. In Maintain Business Roles (App ID “Maintain Business Roles”), find the technical catalog item for F0718.2. Under Business Catalog → Authorization Objects, maintain object F_BKPF_BL.3. For Role A, leave DOC Type (*) = all allowed.4. For Role B, restrict DOC Type = specific type(s) (e.g., SA or Z1).✅ Effect: user can post only permitted document type; if they try to change, system error “Document type not permitted (F5 165)” appears.
Alternative 2 – App variant with UI adaptationFor public-cloud tenants where custom authorizations can’t be fine-tuned:• Use Adapt UI → Create App Variant for F0718.• Pre-set document type (Z1) in the UI layout.• Hide the Document Type field (set Visible = False).• Publish variant to the catalog used by Role B only.✅ Effect: field invisible/unchangeable for those users; Role A keeps original app.
Alternative 3 – Business Role separationCreate two business roles / catalogs:• Role A = standard F0718.• Role B = app variant (locked doc type).Assign respective variant/catalog via Maintain Business Roles app.
Alternative 4 – Validation or BAdI• In Private Cloud / on-premise, use validation (OB28) or BAdI BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT to check document type vs user ID and raise error.• In Public Cloud, limited BAdIs: BAdI FIN_JOURNAL_ENTRY_POST can validate header fields before posting and reject if document type ≠ allowed.
Suggested combination (Public Cloud)→ Use UI variant to hide/lock field for restricted role + authorization F_BKPF_BL to enforce at posting level.
Testing steps1️⃣ Login as Role A → F0718 app → document type editable.2️⃣ Login as Role B → F0718 app variant → field hidden/greyed.3️⃣ Try posting with different type → system rejects if unauthorized.
SAP Notes / References• 3154605 – Journal Entry Templates – fields cannot be locked.• 3246069 – F0718 field control limitations.• KBA 2822493 – F_BKPF_BL authorization usage for document types.• SAP Help: Manage Journal Entries (F0718) → Authorizations.
Final Recommendation✅ Public Cloud: Use App Variant + Authorization restriction.✅ Private Cloud: Optionally add Validation / BAdI for extra enforcement.✅ Document type locking via template alone = not supported.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: DRC - Run Statutory Report - Add next run for the rep...
entry.content:
Hi @G_hind01 ,

You cannot manually “Add Next Run” for non–Ad Hoc statutory reports in DRC.
The next run is generated automatically according to the report’s configured frequency and period logic.
To prepare early or simulate, you can only:

-Use an Ad Hoc variant
-Adjust the reporting period parameters in configuration / job scheduling.

SectionDetails / Explanation
AppRun Statutory Reports (DRC)
Your scenarioYou have successfully run local statutory reports (e.g., VAT, SAF-T, GST, Intrastat, etc.) for October and now want to prepare November and December runs in advance (non–ad hoc reports).
Observed behavior• You can click “Add Next Run” for Ad Hoc reports only.• For periodic reports, there is no “Add Next Run” button visible.
Reason / Root cause• For non–Ad Hoc reports, the runs are generated automatically by the system based on: – Report Definition configuration (reporting frequency: monthly, quarterly, yearly, etc.) – Current reporting period and offset settings.• Therefore, you cannot manually add future runs — they appear only when the next period becomes due according to the configuration.
Where to check frequency definitionApp: Define Statutory Reports (configuration activity ID: 102260 – Define Statutory Reports)or via Manage Your Solution → Application Area: Financial Accounting → Subarea: Statutory Reporting.
Key fields controlling next run- Reporting Frequency (Monthly, Quarterly, Yearly, etc.)- Period Determination Logic (Calendar-based, Fiscal-based)- Earliest Run Date (determines when next period becomes available)- Company Code Assignment (which entities are linked to the report).
How the system generates new run periods• After you complete (or mark as “Ready for Submission” / “Submitted”) a reporting period, the system automatically adds the next period run once the system date crosses into the next reporting period.• No manual creation possible unless the report is configured as Ad Hoc.
Workaround to prepare next period early1️⃣ Go to Manage Statutory Reports (if available for your country/localization).2️⃣ Adjust the Reporting Period determination date (if permitted) to generate next run earlier.3️⃣ For some local reports, you can duplicate the existing report definition and temporarily set it to Ad Hoc = Yes to test upcoming period logic (then revert to standard).
Alternative in certain localizationsSome local content (e.g., Spain SII, India GST, Poland SAF-T) allows creation of future runs manually via “Generate Run” button in Manage Statutory Reports.However, this button appears only when report definition supports Manual Run Creation = Yes.
If you need to schedule future periods systematicallyUse Schedule Statutory Report Generation (Job Template) in Schedule Application Jobs app — available for some local reports. The job automatically creates the next runs once due dates arrive.
Typical behavior by report type 
Ad Hoc ReportsUser can manually click “Add Next Run” anytime.
Periodic Reports (Monthly/Quarterly)Next run created automatically once current period ends or system date ≥ start of next period.
Automated Job-Controlled ReportsManaged through scheduled job templates; user cannot manually create runs.
SAP Reference Notes / Docs- SAP Help Portal → Document and Reporting Compliance, Run Statutory Reports – Creating and Managing Runs.- SAP Note 3241995 – “Run Statutory Reports: Period generation logic”.- SAP KBA 3334919 – “Next run not visible for non-Ad Hoc statutory reports”.
Recommended approach (best practice)✅ Ensure report definition frequency and “Earliest Run Date” are correct.✅ Let system generate November/December runs automatically when period becomes active.✅ For testing upcoming periods, use Ad Hoc copy of the report.
Expected outcome• Non-Ad Hoc (monthly) reports automatically show new run for November once October run is completed and system date ≥ November 1.• December run appears when November period is open.


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.

entry.title: Re: Query on Accounting Principle Config
entry.content:
Hi @SaiSC2 ,

To replicate postings from a source using Local GAAP & Local Currency as Group Currency into a CFIN target using US GAAP & USD as Group Currency:
🔹 Use Accounting Principle Mapping and Currency Mapping in CFIN.
🔹 System automatically converts currencies and aligns ledgers.
🔹 For structural GAAP differences, use separate ledger or BAdI adjustments.

 

AreaDetails / Explanation
Scenario• Source system: Local GAAP (e.g., IFRS/Local) and local currency = Group Currency (e.g., EUR).• Target system (CFIN): US GAAP and Group Currency = USD.• You need to replicate postings from source → CFIN target system, even though accounting principles & group currencies differ.
Key challenge🔹 Source and Target have different accounting principles (e.g., Local GAAP vs. USGAAP).🔹 Source and Target have different group currencies.➡️ Direct replication of journal entries may lead to currency inconsistencies or incorrect valuation logic in target system.
ObjectiveTo correctly bring source postings into CFIN (for US GAAP) while preserving accurate values, and allowing adjustments for different accounting principles.
Recommended approachUse Central Finance (CFIN) with Accounting Principle Mapping + Currency Translation logic enabled.
Key Components Involved1️⃣ SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server) for real-time replication.2️⃣ Central Finance Mapping Framework (FI Mapping, Accounting Principle Mapping, Company Code Mapping, Currency Mapping).3️⃣ Source–Target Accounting Principle Mapping (via Financial Accounting Principle in CFIN customizing).4️⃣ Central Posting Logic (BADI Implementations)* to derive correct target GAAP values if needed.
Configuration StepsSteps
  
1. Define Accounting PrinciplesIn CFIN target: SPRO → Financial Accounting (New) → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Ledgers → Accounting Principle → Define Accounting Principles.
2. Assign Ledgers to Accounting PrinciplesAssign separate ledgers to different GAAPs, e.g.,• Ledger 0L → US GAAP (Leading Ledger)• Ledger 2L → Local GAAP (if needed for reconciliation).
3. Map Source to Target Accounting PrincipleIn CFIN customizing → Cross-System Mapping → Mapping for Accounting → Accounting Principle Mapping.Here, map the source GAAP (e.g., IFRS) to target GAAP (USGAAP).
4. Define Currency MappingEnsure Currency Mapping exists in CFIN (Cross-System Mapping → Currency Mapping).This maps EUR (source) → USD (target group currency).
5. Maintain Exchange Rate Type LogicAssign correct Exchange Rate Type (e.g., M or G) to convert source local currency to target group currency (USD) during replication.Configure via SPRO → CFIN → Accounting Integration → Define Exchange Rate Type for Replication.
6. Enable Document Splitting and Ledger-Specific PostingsEnsure correct ledger assignment and document splitting rules are consistent with US GAAP requirements.
7. Replication via SLTSLT sends FI/CO postings → CFIN staging tables → AIF (Application Interface Framework).During posting, mapping and conversion logic is applied automatically.
8. BAdI Enhancements (if required)Implement BAdIs like:• CFIN_AC_INTERFACE_MODIFY – to adjust accounting principle/currency during replication.• CFIN_CUST_EXCHRATE_DET – to control exchange rate derivation for target system.
9. Reporting and ValidationValidate posting correctness via:• Transaction code FINS_CFIN_DFV_MONITOR (Data consistency).• FINS_CFIN_MAP_MANAGE (Mapping overview).• FINS_CFIN_AIF (Error handling).
Alternative Design OptionIf US GAAP adjustments are significantly different, create separate ledger in CFIN for Local GAAP replication (mirror of source postings) and derive US GAAP via Adjustments / Central Manual Entries (preferred in consolidation environments).
Key Consideration – Group Currency- In source: Group Currency = Local Currency (e.g., EUR).- In CFIN: Group Currency = USD.✅ During replication, the system automatically performs currency conversion using the exchange rate maintained in target (OB08).✅ No manual re-entry required.
Restrictions / Caveats- You cannot post directly to multiple accounting principles in a single replication step.- If Local GAAP → US GAAP adjustments involve structural differences (e.g., capitalization rules), those must be handled as adjustment entries in CFIN.- Always ensure exchange rate consistency between systems to avoid rounding errors.
Validation Tools- CFIN_MONITOR → to check replicated documents.- AIF Monitor → to identify failed mappings or currency mismatches.- Consistency Check Reports (FINS_CFIN_CC).
SAP Reference Notes- SAP Note 2500202 – Currency conversion in CFIN.- SAP Note 2346233 – Mapping framework usage.- SAP Note 2774481 – Accounting principle mapping and replication.- SAP Note 2570014 – CFIN replication with different ledgers/currencies.
Recommended Best Practice✅ Map source accounting principle to US GAAP ledger in target.✅ Enable automatic currency conversion via CFIN currency mapping.✅ Use BAdIs to fine-tune any valuation/currency rules.✅ If differences are large, maintain secondary ledger for Local GAAP tracking in CFIN.
Expected Outcome- Source postings replicate into CFIN correctly, converted into USD for group reporting under US GAAP.- System applies mapping and currency conversion automatically.- Audit trail maintained via AIF logs and mapping framework.

Thanks,

entry.title: Re: CVI Conversion issue
entry.content:
Hi @Shekhard ,

FD32 → UKM000 data replication does not happen automatically during CVI.
You must migrate classic credit data using programs like UKM_TRANSFER_DATA or UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATA after activating FSCM Credit Management.
Once done, the BP UKM000 role will reflect the migrated credit limits and segments.

 

SectionDetails / Explanation
System Context- SAP S/4HANA or S/4HANA Conversion Project (ECC → S/4HANA).- You have completed CVI configuration and CVI_COCKPIT processing.- Business Partner (BP) is created for customers, but UKM000 role is missing / not populated with FD32 data.
Root Cause1️⃣ Classic credit management (transaction FD32) uses Credit Control Area (KNKK table).2️⃣ In S/4HANA, Credit Management is part of SAP Credit Management (FIN-FSCM-CR) and stores data in UKMBP_CMS / UKMBP_CMS_SGM tables.3️⃣ The conversion does not automatically migrate FD32 → UKM000 unless FSCM Credit Management is active and migration steps are executed.
Key UnderstandingFD32 data = Classic Credit Management (FI-AR-CR).UKM000 role = New Credit Management (FSCM).➡️ The system treats them as different architectures. Simple CVI does not transfer FD32 data into UKM tables automatically.
ObjectiveTo migrate FD32 (classic credit data) into Business Partner UKM000 (FSCM Credit Management) role data, so that converted BPs show corresponding credit master data in BP → UKM000 tab.
High-Level Solution FlowClassic FD32 Data (KNKK) → Migration Program (UKM_TRANSFER / UKM_MIGRATION) → BP Role UKM000 / UKMBP_CMS Tables.
Detailed Step-by-Step Solution 
Step 1 – Activate FSCM Credit Management- Ensure FIN-FSCM-CR business function is active.- Transaction: SFW5 → Activate FIN_FSCM_CCD and FIN_FSCM_CCD_INTEGRATION.- Confirm configuration via node: SPRO → Financial Supply Chain Management → Credit Management → Integration with AR/AP.
Step 2 – Check BP Role Assignment- Verify that BP role UKM000 (Credit Management) exists and is assigned to the correct BP grouping.- Transaction: BP → Change mode → add role UKM000 if not auto-assigned.
Step 3 – Migrate FD32 Data to FSCM- Run migration program: UKM_TRANSFER_CUSTOMIZING (to transfer Credit Control Area customizing).- Then execute program: UKM_TRANSFER_DATA (or UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATA) to transfer customer credit master data from KNKK (FD32) → UKM tables.- You can also use transaction UKM_MIGRATION (wizard for both customizing and data).
Step 4 – Verify Mapping of Company Code & Credit Control Area- In S/4HANA, Credit Segment = Company Code (normally).- During migration, ensure credit control area (KNA1-KKBER) correctly maps to credit segment (UKM_SGMNT).- If 1:1 mapping not set, maintain in customizing: SPRO → FSCM → Credit Management → Integration with AR/AP → Define Relationship Between Company Code and Credit Segment.
Step 5 – Execute Migration ReportProgram: UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATAParameters:• Company code• Credit control area• Customer range• Test run (first execute in simulation).➡️ This program reads data from KNKK (FD32) and updates UKMBP_CMS/UKMBP_CMS_SGM.➡️ Automatically creates BP role UKM000 if BP exists.
Step 6 – Check BP After Migration- Transaction: BP → Open the Business Partner.- Switch to Role: UKM000 (Credit Management).- Verify Credit Segment Data tab shows migrated credit limits, risk category, currency, etc.
Step 7 – Validate via Tables / Reports- Table UKMBP_CMS → BP header credit data.- Table UKMBP_CMS_SGM → BP segment data (limit, currency, risk class).- Compare with KNKK (classic).
Step 8 – Reconcile & Activate- Run consistency check report: UKM_CHECK_CREDIT_ACCOUNT.- If needed, assign Credit Segment BP via UKM_BP_CMS_ASSIGN.
Step 9 – Optional Enhancements- If special mapping logic is needed (e.g., multiple credit control areas), enhance BAdI UKM_CREDIT_ACCOUNT_ASSIGNMENT to control how migration maps credit accounts to segments.
Key Transactions- FD32 → Classic credit master.- UKM_BP → BP Credit Management (UKM000 role).- UKM_TRANSFER_DATA / UKM_MIGRATION → Data migration.- UKM_CHECK_CREDIT_ACCOUNT → Validation.- BP → Business Partner maintenance.
Post-Migration Testing✅ Create a sales order → system should pick credit data from BP UKM000.✅ Run report FDM_COLL_SEND_CUSTOMER if credit data should flow to collections management.
  
Common IssuesIssue
  
UKM000 role missingAdd manually or re-run UKM_MIGRATION with correct BP mapping.
Credit limit not transferredCheck credit segment mapping (Company Code ↔ Credit Control Area).
Risk class missingVerify customizing transfer via UKM_TRANSFER_CUSTOMIZING.
Multiple Credit Control Areas in sourceHandle via manual assignment or enhancement BAdI.
FD32 data not visible after migrationEnsure FIN-FSCM-CR active and UKM_BP roles generated correctly.
SAP Notes & References- SAP Note 2691534 – Migration of Credit Management Data to UKM_BP.- SAP Note 2603674 – UKM_MIGRATION report usage.- SAP Note 2777273 – Credit Segment mapping guidance.- SAP Help: CVI Conversion with FSCM Credit Management Migration.
Expected Outcome✅ FD32 (Classic Credit Management) data migrated into UKM tables.✅ BP role UKM000 automatically updated/created.✅ Credit limits, risk class, control area appear correctly under BP → UKM000 tab.✅ Sales and AR processes use new Credit Management logic.

Thanks,

entry.title: SAC Currency Sign for Singapore Dollar
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I'm working with SAP Analytics Cloud and need help formatting Singapore Dollar (SGD) values to display as currency symbols like "SG$" or "S$" in my stories.

Here's my current setup and issue:

- I’m using imported data, and in the model, I’ve set the currency to a fixed value of "SGD".

- In SAC Administration, I’ve changed "Show Currency As" to "Symbol" (instead of "ISO Code") to display currency symbols.

This works for other currencies: AUD shows as "AU$", HKD as "HK$", and USD as "$". However, SGD still displays as the ISO code "SGD" instead of a symbol like "SG$" or "S$".

Has anyone encountered this? Is there a setting or workaround to get SGD to display with its currency symbol in SAC? Any tips would be appreciated!

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: Can't find archived documents in external repository...
entry.content: @Chris1973, you are right, many companies nowadays are using third-party SAP certified products, such as YAC for SharePoint for example, ABAP add-on especially made to answer the above requirements..

entry.title: Re: Mastering the Data Deluge: A Comprehensive Guide to SAP Data Strategy and Archiving
entry.content:
Thanks for this very useful blog.

You mention YAC which is indeed an SAP add-on (pure ABAP, no middleware needed) that facilitates the integration of attachments and documents from SAP ERP and S/4HANA systems (also RISE) with various Document Management Systems (DMS) both in the cloud and on-premises.

These last years it's mainly the YAC for SharePoint version that has been used by many customers to store SAP attachments in automatically generated folders with intelligent attributes, in SharePoint / Teams / OneDrive / AzureBlob.

Note that there is also a similar solution named SA2S working for all SaaS business solutions such as SuccessFactors
SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), Oracle Fusion Cloud, Workday, NetSuite (Oracle) and even SAP S/4HANA Cloud !

entry.title: Re: No payment media were created because of manual appro...
entry.content:
Hello Samuel,

I hope you are doing well.

Please see the SAP KBA below:

3672167 - Payment Program Error: "No payment media were created because of manual approval needed."https://me.sap.com/notes/3672167/E

  • Using Manage Bank Account app; In the Payment Approver tab/section of the relevant House Bank Account, ensure there are no approvers defined, especially if the customer intends for payments to be auto-approved or only approved via a separate flexible workflow.
  • If a workflow is intentionally active (Scope Item J78/J77), the next action is for the designated user to approve the payment batch in the Approve Bank Payments Fiori app. Once approved, the payment media generation will complete.
  • If no flexible workflow is set up, the check on the Manage Bank Accounts app is critical to ensure no unintended approvals are required at the bank master data level.

Best Regards

Fabio

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Beyond Manual: SuccessFactors Custom MDF & Integration Center for Automated Reimbursement Pr
entry.content:
Hi @Berg_Song ,

Thanks for your feedback. In this solution, the reimbursement request already goes through a workflow that includes the payroll team as approvers. Once the request is approved, the total amount is automatically transferred to the Non-Recurring Payment. (WF can be triggered if NRP is updated manually from UI) 

Additionally, we have enabled the “Pending Data” option in our source MDF object, so only approved requests are reflected in the NRP using IC. 

Regarding your second point, if the data volume is big, then yes, splitting the integration is recommended.

entry.title: Re: SAP from me Berechtigungen um SSF Meldungen zu bearbe...
entry.content:
Regarding to your question, please refer to KBA 1296527 - How to create a support case (contact SAP Product Support) - SAP for Me

  • Report a Technical Problem
  • Send Cases to SAP
  • Display Cases
  • Display All Cases
  • Close Cases
  • Display cloud data（(in your case, the SF installation is *）

For creating service request, you may refer to 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: BZSTDOC
entry.content:
Hi  cmfs5

For this issue, I kindly ask you to please check and apply the following SAP Notes:

1873607 - Optimized Log Configuration and Database Size for Integration Framework

1873559 - B1iF_Using the DB Purge Tool for Database Size Reduction

And also, I kindly ask you to double  check below mentioned article to control the Integration Framework logs https://help.sap.com/doc/9c200d7b20af4b5f9f29bafdb2401579/9.0/en-US/B1if%20Log%20Maintenance.pdf

1. Make sure that the B1i debug settings are set as a Production environment, as detailed in SAP Note 1873607, section "6. Best practice: Log configuration for production servers".

2. Use the B1i → Tools → Log Mass Deletion, to delete unnecessary logging information and maintain the size of the B1i database.

3. Perform the steps below to release any unused or fragmented space (see KBA 3107274, section A.8):

    3.1. Schedule some downtime on the HANA Server, making sure there are no connected users

    3.2. Stop the server tools, B1i and any other services that connect to the HANA instance

    3.3. Perform a Full Backup of the instance

    3.4. Restart the HANA Instance

    3.5. Execute the following SQL statements in HANA Studio:

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM DATAVOLUME 120 DEFRAGMENT;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOG;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM COLUMN LOB SPACE;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM ROW LOB SPACE;

    3.6. Start the Server tools and other services again.

Check if BZSTDOC table size is reduced after this.

Thank You.

Kimd Regards
Nidhi
SAP Support

entry.title: Leave accrual based on working days i previous year
entry.content:
Hi @Volker_Ruof / @StephanieCR  / experts / product owners,

We are busy exploring a configuration scenario where the annual leave entitlement is determined by the number of working days in the previous year.

A working day is defined as:

  • A normal working day

  • Working on a non-working day

  • More than 4 hours of overtime booked in a day

  • Absence due to a work accident, strike, etc.
    (There are a few other basic conditions, but these are the main ones.)

The working day checks have been achieved using time valuations, which add to a counter in a time collector. This correctly calculates the number of working days.

The accrual period and account validity are based on the employee’s hire date. For example, the number of working days from 1 June 2024 to 31 May 2025 determines the entitlement for 1 June 2025.

This would have been straightforward if all employees shared the same accrual period, as we could use a flexible-period time collector. However, because the period differs per employee (based on hire date), this becomes more complex.

We are currently considering two possible approaches and would appreciate your feedback or alternative suggestions:

Scenario 1:
Leverage a workaround within the decision or calculation rule (details can be shared privately with product owners or experts) to manipulate or assign values to the time valuation/time type group, thereby determining working days for the relevant annual period.

Scenario 2:
Use a daily time collector that writes to a custom object. The accrual rule would then read the value from this custom object, populated via an onSave rule in the timesheet or time type groups.
The downside is potential performance issues, and it would not automatically capture retrospective timesheet changes unless the timesheet is re-saved.

Would love to hear your thoughts, feedback or alternative approaches.

Thank you!

 

SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series – Colors, Creativity, and Canvases – Sandra Solís
entry.content:
Just like smarchesini enjoys discovering and connecting with places through
running, I also love to connect with the places I visit — but through painting. I’m
excited to continue the SAP Community Hobbies series by sharing another passion
that takes me away from the keyboard yet still connects back in surprising ways:
drawing and painting.

A Little About Me and My Hobby

Hello everyone! My name is Sandra Solís, I’m an ABAP developer from Mexico and also the creator of the YouTube channel Mundo Abaper, where I share ABAP content in Spanish. Like Sebastiano, I enjoy running, making ABAP content of course, but the hobby that truly wins my heart is drawing and painting.

Over the years, I’ve explored many techniques—colored pencils, charcoal, watercolor, acrylics, and even coffee painting. For me, every medium has its own charm and challenge.

How It All Started

My journey with art began when I was 15 years old, in secondary school, when I took an art class, and that’s when I started practicing this hobby. What started as curiosity became a lifelong practice—20 years now! Since then, my sketchbooks, canvases, and brushes have been my constant companions.

What I Love Most

When I paint, the world slows down. It’s just me and the canvas. This hobby gives me a moment of peace but also sparks unexpected creativity for my programming work. Many times, while drawing, a solution to an ABAP problem suddenly comes to my mind.

Connecting Art with SAP

At first glance, painting may seem far from the SAP world. But here’s where I find the link:

Visual thinking: Sketching helps me structure ideas, the same way I design solutions. It also helps me take notes with small drawings, which makes it easier to understand what I study and read.

  • Creative problem-solving: When I feel overwhelmed or can’t find a solution, I step away and start painting. Suddenly, while I’m painting, some answers appear, helping me get unstuck and find solutions.
  • Content creation: For my Mundo Abaper videos, I often use drawings and visual notes to explain concepts more clearly.

So while brushes and SAP might seem unrelated, creativity is the bridge between them.

Challenges Along the Way

Art is not always easy. Portraits, for example, are especially challenging—capturing the essence of a face requires patience and practice. Learning each new technique (like watercolor vs. charcoal) also brings its own learning curve. I’ve overcome these challenges through courses and, most importantly, constant practice.

Proud Moments

Some highlights of my artistic journey:

  • Portraits of the SAP Developer Advocates—painted with coffee!

 

  • My travel journal, a tiny handmade sketchbook filled with paintings of the beautiful places I’ve visited, here I show just a few ones on my sketchbook . 

    

    

  • A charcoal portrait of Madona

  • My favorite superhero in colored pencils.

  • And one special project: a handmade badge painted with acrylics that I use as a background for my videos.

I even have a iman that I use as watercolor pallet of Paint !!! perfect match between computers and painting, dont you think??

 

Myths About Painting

Many people believe painting or drawing is only for those “born with talent.” I strongly disagree. With a good mentor and consistent practice, anyone can improve—yes, even to the level of Van Gogh!

Tips for Beginners

  • Start with the fundamentals, no matter which painting technique you choose, they all share the same, learn lines, dots, perspective, volume, shadows, light, and composition.
  • Once you’re comfortable, choose a technique you like—watercolor, pencils, charcoal—and deepen your skills there.

Where to Learn More

There are countless resources, both free and paid. My personal recommendation: start with YouTube tutorials to get the basics, then take structured courses to refine your technique.

As you can see, art, is more than a hobby—it’s a way to recharge, connect with us, and even find inspiration for our SAP work. I’d love to hear from you too: What hobby fuels your creativity outside of SAP?

Passing the Baton

Next, I’d like to forward to Riney Riley, who will share an exciting hobby of skydiving

entry.title: Automating SAP Business One Sales Reporting with n8n, AI, and Telegram
entry.content:
Introduction

This workflow integrates SAP Business One data through the Service Layer with Google Sheets and Telegram. The purpose of this workflow is to automate sales reporting process by automatically retrieving new sales orders, updating google sheets with new orders, and delivering daily summaries via Telegram. Google’s Gemma AI used in this workflow to add extra insights and analyze the consolidated data in order to highlighting top performers, upcoming due dates, and extracting sales trends by removing manual data exports and providing real-time visibility of sales performance.

 

Technical Architecture

The workflow includes two main stages. First, it connects to the Service Layer to retrieve sales orders data with the help of OData queries, filters out duplicates orders, and appends new orders to Google Sheets. Second, it uses JavaScript code to format the data, create structured AI prompts, and deliver the finalized reports through a Telegram Bot. (The social platfrom can be vary based on the user requirements.)

Prerequisites

  • SAP Business One Access: A valid database with authorized username, password, and active Service Layer. (SBODemoUS data used in this tutorial)
  • Docker: Docker Desktop used to deploy n8n.
  • Google Account: Google Sheets and Google API setup.
  • Telegram Account: A Telegram account to create a bot and obtain a user ID for notifications. (this can be applicable to any other platform)
  • n8n Account: n8n account for deploying and configuring workflows.
  • Javascript: JavaScript syntax used to in n8n nodes.

Implementation Steps

The workflow follows these stages:

  1. Deploying n8n on the server
  2. SAP Business One Integration
  3. Validate SAP Business One data
  4. Create automated workflow
  5. Google Sheets Data Synchronization
  6. Sales Analysis in Google Sheets
  7. AI-Powered Sales Insights
  8. Automated Reporting to Telegram

Implementation

The process starts by checking the latest sales orders in SAP Business One:

Next step is to deploy n8n in Docker and set up Service Layer using HTTP nodes for login and data retrieval. Example OData query would be like this:

https://server:50000/b1s/v1/Orders?$select=DocEntry,DocDate,CardName&$orderby=DocEntry desc&$top=10

A JavaScript code node also handles duplicate checking. It can grab existing rows from Google Sheets, pulls out DocEntry values, and filters SAP data to include only new sales orders. This prevent duplication when the workflow runs multiple times.

For having AI analysis, a JavaScript node formats the sales data into a prompt and calculates daily totals, identify top performers, and computes monthly averages. The prompt asks Gemma AI to generate a report with a performance summary, and alerts. Finally, the Telegram node sends the formatted report to specific user id, including the date, total sales, top performers, AI insights, and upcoming due dates.

Final Thoughts

This workflow automates sales order retrieval from SAP Business One through Service Layer and syncs new orders to Google Sheets. By using n8n, it delivers daily reports via Telegram and remove the need for manual data exports. The implementation requirements are SAP Business One Service Layer, Docker, n8n, and JavaScript to perform calculations with AI assistance. Although calculations can be done with just code, AI can help to get extra insights based on the given prompt. Beyond sales reporting, this approach can be applied to other modules such as purchasing, inventory management, or crm and making it a cost-effective alternative to enterprise automation platforms.

 

Resources 

The full guide is available as a PDF with step-by-step instructions and screenshots. The JavaScript code is in GitHub with comments.

  • Full Guide PDF
  • GitHub Repository

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni
SAP Business One Consultant

  • LinkedIn
  • Portfolio

entry.title: Re: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
entry.content:
@nageshcaparthy - Thanks for a well-documented guide.
I observed one thing, in your guide, when creating the SAP_COM_0193 communication arrangement, it is mentioned to use the S4HANA URL domain as the HOST. 

However in the SAP Mission -

Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it is mentioned to use the IAS tenant (Cloud Identity Service) domain as the HOST. 
 
This was possibly the reason why no user roles were replicated from S4HANA system to SAP Build Workzone and Joule considered everyone as unauthorised users. Due to this, Joule never answered our queries correctly or atleast the answers were very generic and vague.
After I made the changes in the HOST, the IPS was able to extract the user roles from S4HANA cloud system and replicate them to BUILD workzone. With the authorization of the users now available, Joule became more accurate and decisive and was now able to answer queries and also show navigational links based on the queries.

entry.title: Saudi Arabia: Violation and Sanction
entry.content:
What is the issue we are trying to solve?

In accordance with Saudi labor law, businesses often face several violations and sanctions that can adversely affect employee growth and compensation. To address these challenges, we have implemented a robust solution using SAP’s Employee Central and Employee Central Payroll. This administrative service is designed to effectively capture penalties, occurrences, and deduction amounts, ensuring compliance and supporting a fair and transparent workplace for employees.

What are the main components of the solution?

In this blog, we’ll walk through the end-to-end design for capturing violations and sanctions in SAP SuccessFactors, ensuring both compliance and transparency.

You need to bring several components together to build one solution that can achieve your goal
  1. Picklist
  2. Object definition
  3. business rules
  4. Integration center
  5. Configure people profile
  6. Wrapping Up Phase One
  7. What’s Next?
are you ready, let's start with our first process

 

1. Picklists

1.1 Violation Category

Where it includes 3 categories based on Saudi labor law:

  • Working Hours Violations
  • Work Organization Violations
  • Worker Behavior Violations

 

1.2Violation Type 

Which is the child picklist for one of violation categories we must map it with.

 

Note: to create any picklist please go to Picklist center tool or from import export Data to upload it *you can use our template as reference to create or upload the violation categories and types*

"Now let's create the object definitions"

2. Object Definition

2.1 Object definition for violation Pranet:

As part of building a custom solution to manage employee violations and related sanctions in SAP SuccessFactors, I started by creating a parent MDF object named "Violations and Sanctions" (cust_ViolationsAndSanctions).

This object serves as the main record holder that links employee violations to the disciplinary actions taken, allowing HR to track and manage policy enforcement efficiently.

Key Highlights:

  • Effective Dating: Set to Basic to track start and end dates.
  • API Visibility: Editable, enabling future integrations or automations.
  • Subject User Field: Uses UserID to tie the record to the employee.
  • Object Category: User Transactional, making it available in employee profiles if needed.
  • Association: A one-to-many composite association has been created to link this object with a detailed child object that will store specific violation/sanction actions. 

2.2 Child object of violation and Sanction

To support the parent record, I created a child object named "Violations and Sanctions Details" (cust_ViolationsAndSanctionsDetails). This object is designed to capture detailed information about each individual violation or disciplinary action linked to the main case.

It’s structured with multiple custom fields, enabling granular tracking of both violation types and the corresponding sanctions.

Key Highlights:

  • Effective Dating: From Parent — ensures synchronization with the parent object.
  • Data Model: Includes a rich set of fields, including:
    • cust_ViolationCategory (Picklist)
    • cust_ViolationType (Picklist)
    • cust_SanctionType (Picklist)
    • cust_Occurrence (Number of times the violation occurred)
    • cust_SeverityLevel (Picklist)
    • cust_ActionTaken (String)
    • cust_StartDate / cust_EndDate (Dates for sanction period)
    • cust_AmountDeducted (Decimal — for fines or deductions)
    • cust_Comment (Long text — additional notes)
  • Reference Fields:
    • cust_EmployeeName (User)
    • cust_CreatedBy, cust_CreatedDate, etc. — for auditing
  • Association: This child object is linked via a composite association to the parent object cust_ViolationsAndSanctions, which controls its lifecycle.

This structure allows the system to hold multiple violation/sanction records per employee under one umbrella case, offering full flexibility and traceability.

 

"With our picklists and MDF objects ready, it’s time to connect the dots"

2.2.1 Mapping picklist and business rules Business Rules to the Violation & Sanction details (object definition)

After creating child object definition, you have to map our picklists (violation category and type) to it.

Violation Category

Violation Type:

 

2.2.2 Mapping the business rule with child object definition has been explained in below screenshot where the configuration of these business rules will be described later.

2.3 Sanction lookup object definition

To enhance automation and flexibility in managing disciplinary actions, I created a lookup object called "Sanctions Lookup" (cust_SanctionsLookup). This object acts as a reference table that links violation types to predefined sanction types and their associated penalty percentages.

It enables easy maintenance of sanction rules and supports business rule logic for automated decision-making.

Key Highlights:

  • Effective Dating: None — since this is a static lookup table.
  • Status: Active
  • API Visibility: Not Visible — internal use only.
  • Object Category: Generic Object Change Requests — indicates it’s maintained via MDF UI.

Field Design:

  • cust_ViolationType: Picklist — the category of violation
  • cust_SanctionType01 to cust_SanctionType04: Strings — predefined sanctions for each level
  • cust_DailyRatePerc01 to cust_DailyRatePerc04: Numbers — penalty percentage tied to each sanction level

This design supports a tiered approach, allowing different sanctions and deduction percentages based on the severity or repetition of the violation.

 

 

Note:

You have to upload one excel file after creating this object in Import and Export Data to capture all sanction types and rate

*you can find the full template under our Mena user Group*

"Now that we’ve set up our objects and picklists, it’s time to bring logic into action — let’s start building the business rules that will drive our Violation and Sanction process."

3. Business rules 

3.1 Violation Count

Reset Violation Count After 6 Months

To ensure fair evaluation of employee behavior over time, I created a business rule that resets the violation occurrence count if the last recorded violation happened more than 6 months ago.

This rule helps HR treat old violations as expired, allowing employees to rebuild a clean record if no further infractions occur within the defined period.

3.2 Calculate Sanction Amount

First Business rule we will explain is Calculate Sanction Amount As part of automating the sanctions process, I created a business rule to dynamically calculate the sanction amount based on the selected violation and its associated penalty percentage from the lookup object.

 

3.3 Violation Evaluation

To support consistent enforcement of disciplinary policies, I created a business rule that evaluates the number of occurrences for each violation type. Based on this count, the system automatically determines the appropriate sanction type and its corresponding penalty rate by referencing the Sanctions Lookup object.

"After completing the business rules that automate the evaluation and sanction logic, it’s time to move to the final stage — integrating the violation penalties with payroll through the Integration Center."

4. Integration Center (deduction record)

After setting up the objects and business rules, the final task is to export the calculated sanction amount into Employee Central’s Non‑Recurring Deduction (NRD) portlet . Here’s how to accomplish that:

4.1 Choose Integration Type

4.2 configure Fields

Mapping violation and sanction details and one-time payment

  • Pay Component (payComponentCode) String<<--PayComponent (cust_PayComponent) from Violations and Sanctions Details
  • Issue Date (payDate) DateTime<<--ViolationDate (cust_ViolationDate) from Violations and Sanctions Details
  • User ID (userId) String(100)<<--Violations and Sanctions_UserID (cust_ViolationsAndSanctions_UserID) from Violations and Sanctions Details

  • Currency (currencyCode) String(20)<<--SAR
  • Amount (value) Double<<--SanctionAmount (cust_SanctionAmount) from Violations and Sanctions Details 
4.3 Filter and Sort

To apply filters that limit which records are selected for processing/export based on date/time and other criteria. This is especially useful for incremental loads or scheduled integrations.

These help filter data based on when records were modified or effective.

  1. Modified Since Query Mode:
    • Modified Since – Only fetch records changed since a given time.
    • Effective Dated – Based on start or end dates.
    • Dropdown with options like:
    • You selected Modified Since, meaning you're pulling only records that were modified after a certain time.
  1.  Effective As Of / Effective From / Effective To:
  • These are optional date filters based on the record's effective date range (usually for MDF objects).
  • Example: You might use “Effective From” = 01/01/2024 to fetch records starting in 2024.
  1.  Last Run Time:
  • Shows the timestamp of the last time this integration was run.

4.4 Scheduling & Review and Run

As the final step in the Integration Center configuration, it is essential to schedule the integration to run daily at a specific time to ensure consistent and timely data replication. This guarantees that any updates or changes are processed automatically without manual intervention.

After scheduling, utilize the "Review and Run" functionality to verify that the integration setup is functioning correctly. This step allows you to review the configuration, where you can also download a report to check if any error happen.

"With the integration setup complete, the next step is to return to the MDF configuration to refine the object behavior, field mappings, and any additional enhancements needed for end-user visibility."

5. Add the MDF

5.1 Manage Configure UI:

Step-by-Step Process to Create the UI

  1. Navigate to "Manage Configuration UI"
  • Go to Admin Center > Manage Configuration UI
  • Click Create New
  1. Select the Base Object
  • Choose: Violations and Sanctions
    • This is your custom MDF object that stores the core data like UserID, Effective Start Date, and other violation-related fields.
  1. Configure Header Section (Parent Object)

The top section contains key fields from the main object:

  • UserID: Employee for whom the violation is being recorded.
  • Effective Start Date: When the violation record becomes active.
  • external Name: Usually auto-filled or manually entered for reporting/search purposes.

  1. Add Child Object Section (VS)

This section represents entries from a composite child object (named something like “VS”):

  • Violation Category: Picklist to classify the type (e.g., Attendance, Conduct).
  • Violation Type: Specific type within the category.
  • Violation Date: When the violation occurred.
  • Occurrence: A calculated or input field indicating how many times this violation has occurred.

     

 

  • You can click “Details” to see or edit extended child object fields (e.g., sanction rate, type, amount, etc.).

  1. Field Customization and Layout
  • You may add, hide, reorder, or group fields for better clarity.
  • Optionally, use rule-based visibility or field-level permissions to control access.
  1. Save the UI
  • Click Save to publish the UI.
  • This makes it available via Manage Data or People Profile (if configured

 

5.2 People profile

To allow HR teams and authorized users to view or manage violation and sanction records directly from the employee's profile, we need to configure a custom portlet in the People Profile. Go to:

  1. Admin Center > Configure People Profile
  2. Choose the Profile Section where you'd like to add the portlet (e.g., under Employee Info or Custom Sections)
  3. Click “Add Block”, then choose:
    • Block Type: MDF-based
    • MDF Object: Violations and Sanctions (cust_VS)
  4. Set the Title: You can name the section "Violations and Sanctions" or customize as needed.

Note: don’t forget to set the Permission role for your HR admin or any other users

 

  • Note: To ensure accurate tracking and avoid data duplication in both violation history and payroll deductions, we recommend that users:
  • Edit the existing violation record and update it with the new occurrence details, rather than creating a new entry for each incident.

6. Wrapping Up Phase One

With this first phase, we've successfully laid the foundation for managing employee violations and sanctions in SAP SuccessFactors. This included building:

  • A structured parent-child object model for capturing violations and related sanctions
  • A lookup object to define policy rules and penalties
  • Key business rules to automate evaluation, calculation, and reset logic

This setup empowers HR teams to handle disciplinary actions in a consistent, fair, and data-driven manner.

7. What’s Next?

In the upcoming phase, we plan to extend this framework by integrating:

  • Time tracking data (e.g., lateness, absence) to trigger violations automatically
  • Other HR processes like grievance ,

With this setup, the Violation Management solution becomes a fully connected and compliant process that strengthens transparency and fairness across the workforce. The full blog on Violations and Sanctions is in progress and will soon be shared in the MENA SAP User Group space — a place for us to exchange ideas, share feedback, and learn from each other’s experiences.

Stay tuned for Phase Two

entry.title: SAP Ariba Sourcing & Contracts 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
SAP Ariba Contracts - Feature highlights

AI Copilot Joule in SAP Ariba Contracts (SCONTR-1279)

Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, is now available in SAP Ariba Contracts. Joule uses a conversational interface to help users complete tasks efficiently.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Supplier Eligibility Validation in Contract Workspaces (SCONTR-1445)

This feature enables buyers to set supplier eligibility criteria using supplier registration and qualification statuses from SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance. It ensures that only suppliers who meet the specified eligibility criteria are included in a contract. These criteria can be validated during various stages, such as during contract creation, publication, or when transferring contract data and line items to integrated external systems like SAP ERP.

View implementation details and more here.

 

 

SAP Ariba Sourcing - Feature highlights

Ability to Block Access to Classic Sourcing for Project or Event Creation

(PSOURCE-1452)

This feature blocks product sourcing users from creating sourcing projects and requests in the classic SAP Ariba Sourcing interface. To create sourcing projects or events, users can use the guided sourcing interface, which streamlines the process and helps users complete more projects with less effort.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Add Plants to Material Line Items in Hybrid Mode

(PSOURCE-1468)

This feature allows you to associate a plant with material line items (not associated with any BOMs) in hybrid mode within product sourcing. This improves the creation of Purchase Info Records (PIRs) by automatically collecting prices for material line items in product sourcing.

Business End User Tasks

Creating a Purchase Info Record from a Material Line Item Linked to a Plant

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Upload CSV File to Autofill Term Values for Material Quote Events in Product Sourcing

(SOURCE-1641)

 

This feature provides system administrators an interface to upload a CSV file that includes predefined term values. These values are used to autofill term values when a new material quote event is created in product sourcing.

Previously, the system prefilled term values in a material quote event only from matching terms in the most recently awarded event. As a result, users had to enter term values manually for every new material quote event.

Now, the system prefills term values from a CSV file uploaded by the system administrator. When a new material quote event is created, the system reuses term values based on the following values:

  • TermID

  • TermName

  • MaterialID

  • SAPPlantID

  • SAPSupplierID

This feature is supported for Approved Manufacturer List (AML) suppliers only.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Add, Update, Remove URLs in Guided Sourcing Full Projects

(SOURCE-2542)

 

With this feature, project owners can add, update, and delete URLs in the Events and other documents section of a guided sourcing full project.

The option to add URLs is added under Create > Document in the Events and other documents section in guided sourcing full projects.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

View implementation details and more here.

 

Exclude Reverted Savings Allocations in Analytical Reports in Guided Sourcing

(SOURCE-2559)

This feature ensures that when draft savings allocations are reverted to the published state, the draft allocations are discarded. Consequently, only active (non-reverted) allocations are included in analytical reports generated from savings forms in guided sourcing full projects.

Previously, analytical reports generated from savings forms in guided sourcing full projects included all savings allocations, including those reverted from drafts. With this feature, these reports now only include active (non-reverted) savings allocations.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Export All Rows from Content Tables in Guided Sourcing Events

(SOURCE-2590)

 

This feature enables buyer users to export the complete set of rows from content tables within guided sourcing events.

Changes to the User Interface

  • The Export all rows option is added to the download icon () for the following event pages in guided sourcing:

    • The Monitor page: In the Items that needs quotes and the Questions, requirements, and attachments tables

    • The Award page: In the Award allocation and Questions, requirements, and attachments tables

View implementation details and more here.

 

Additional Contract Workspace Types in Guided Sourcing Full Projects

(SOURCE-2595)

 

This feature adds additional contract workspace document type options to guided sourcing full projects.

Currently, in the Events and other documents section of guided souring full projects, you can create a Contract workspace document as only the Procurement type. This feature adds the following additional Contract workspace document types:

  • Sales

  • Internal

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Import and Export Event Content in XLSX Format in Sourcing

(SOURCE-2596)

This feature enables buyers to import and export event content in SAP Ariba Sourcing in the XLSX format.

Previously, event content could only be exported and imported in the XLS format. With this feature, both XLS and XLSX formats are supported. While XLSX is set as the default export format, you can still opt for XLS based on your preference.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Communication Support in SAP Business Network Discovery Postings for Sourcing Events 

(SOURCE-2640)

This feature enables communication between buyers and suppliers in SAP Business Network Discovery postings for sourcing events. Buyers can directly respond to supplier-initiated questions, send messages to suppliers, and receive responses within the event posting.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Automatic Initial Offer Submissions in Guided Sourcing 

(SOURCE-2647)

 

This feature adds the ability to copy participants and bids from a past event to a new event and use the past bids as initial bid submissions in the new event.

Previously in guided sourcing, buyer users needed to use a multi-round event to reuse bids as initial bids for subsequent rounds. Users couldn't copy bids from a past single event to a new single event. Now, buyer users can copy participants and items with their associated bids from past single events and reuse the bids as initial bids in a new single event.

For the buyer, this feature ensures that supplier bids remain unchanged between events, without the need for a multi-round event. This also gives suppliers the option to not login and interface with the event unless they want to modify their bid, which saves time for the supplier.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Generate Event Summary in Guided Sourcing Using Generative AI (SOURCE-2670)

 

This feature enables buyer users to generate event summary in guided sourcing utilizing generative AI capabilities.

The summary is generated using the following data from the sourcing event: ID,Title,Description,Type,Base Language,Currency,Owner,Display Version,Contract Months,Contract Effective Date,Contract Expiration Date,Baseline Spend,Target Saving Percentage,Create Date,Last Modified,Origin,Template, and Supplier Bids.

The summary is generated in the event's base language, not the user's locale. It is created at the event level, so all users can see the same summary. If a user chooses to regenerate the summary, it is based on the data visible to that user, not the overall event data.

Note: This premium feature is available at no cost during the trial period.

View implementation details and more here.

 

View Predecessor Projects in Analytical Reports in Guided Sourcing 

(SOURCE-2694)

 

This feature enables you to view predecessor project details in analytical reports for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing.

Previously, predecessor project details were not included in analytical reports for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing. With this feature, you can now add the Predecessor Project column on the Pivot Layout page of the report wizard when creating an analytical report. Once added, these details will appear in the Predecessor Project column in reports. However, data from projects originally created using the classic SAP Ariba Sourcing interface will appear in the Based on Project column instead of the new Predecessor Project column.

Changes to the User Interface

On the Pivot Layout page of the analytical report wizard, a new field, Predecessor Project, is added for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Access Controls for Task Comments 

(SOURCE-2716)

 

This feature adds access controls for task comments in guided sourcing full projects.

You can now specify which user groups can access task comments in a guided sourcing full project. Only users with the specified access permissions, or the Project Owner, can see an access controlled comment. Project Owners can view all task comments. Access controls are chosen below the comment. Comments that do not use access controls are visible to all project members.

Changes to the User Interface

Task detail pages now include Access control options below the the comment field. Click the button on the right side of the Access control field to choose options.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Make Counter-offers in Guided Sourcing Events 

(SSINDUSTRY-517)

This feature enables buyers to propose counteroffers to suppliers during a new round of a sourcing event. A counteroffer is a special type of negotiation round in multi-round bidding, giving buyers an additional way to secure competitive pricing from suppliers.

Previously, buyers could not propose a take-it-or-leave-it offer to suppliers.

With this enhancement, buyers can do the following:

  • Set a specific price as a counteroffer in a new round.

  • Share the counteroffer with selected suppliers.

Supplier can respond to the counter offer in the following manner:

  • If suppliers accept, the counteroffer price is recorded as their submitted quote for that line item. Buyers can then either proceed to awarding or start another negotiation round.

  • If there is no response from suppliers, their previously submitted quote remains valid and continues in the event.

View implementation details and more here.

 

 

 

Stay connected with our community for more insights and updates:

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link and for CIM customers- P2P link 
  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • What’s New

entry.title: XPORG and XEORG authorization fields are not being restricted to assigned values
entry.content:
Hello,

I am currently working on a project where the customer has made XPORG (Purchasing Organization) and XEORG (Planning and Execution Organization) organizational authorization fields. However, end users are able to see values outside of what is assigned to them in these fields.

When I checked user trace, I found that a user going into a transaction that would have an authority check for these fields is not passing an authority check or at least it is not being logged by user trace. Does anyone know what I can do to make sure users do not access values beyond those assigned to them for these two specific fields?

To give some additional information:
- Correct authorization has been given to users and roles do not contain the values they are able to access
- There are no XPGRP (Purchasing Group) and XEGRP (Planning and Execution Group) values added to the system

entry.title: Usage of standard Workflow Steps reuse library in your custom free-styled Fiori apps
entry.content:
Hi All,

During the development of a custom free-styled UI5 app, I received a request to integrate the workflow steps component from a standard app into the custom app.

The Component is used in different standard SAP apps, and it normally looks like this:

In the standard SAP Fiori apps, this component can show different workflow steps of a particular document, and if you press one line item, it will navigate to an object page where it shows a bit more details of this step.

The requirement I received is to show the component in my custom app's object page. Only columns Type, Name, Status, and Recipients in the list should be visible, and the line item navigation should be removed.

Here is what I achieved in my app:

View

Add below ComponentContainer into the correct page section.

<uxap:ObjectPageSection title="{i18n>prApprovalDetails}" titleUppercase="false">
  <uxap:subSections>
    <uxap:ObjectPageSubSection id="workflowPRSection" title="{i18n>prApprovalDetails}">
      <core:ComponentContainer id="workflowPRComponentContainer" propagateModel="true" height="100%"/>
    </uxap:ObjectPageSubSection>
  </uxap:subSections>
</uxap:ObjectPageSection>

 

Controller

Function to create approval details component, using re-use library stworkflowinstance. 

This whole createComponent part was found in one of the standard Fiori app, which consumed the workflow steps library, and I edited it by the request I received to make it work.

_loadPoConWfContainer: function (workflowInstanceId, scenarioID, ID, parentControlId) {
  let _parentControl = this.byId(parentControlId);
  _parentControl.setBusy(true);
  let sWorkflowInstanceId = workflowInstanceId;
  let sScenarioID = scenarioID;
  if (!this.oPoWfComponent) {
    var _control = this.byId(ID);
    let oPoWfComponent = sap.ui
    .getCore()
    .createComponent({
      name: "sap.io.bpm.sworkfloweditor.lib.reuse.stworkflowinstance",
      async: true,
      title: "{{workflowComponentTitle}}",
      settings: {
        objectIdentifier: sWorkflowInstanceId,
        scenarioId: sScenarioID,
        objectContext: "empty string",
      },
    })
    .then(
      function (successValue) {
        let oWorkflowComponent = successValue;
        oWorkflowComponent.setScenarioId(scenarioID);
        oWorkflowComponent.setObjectIdentifier(sWorkflowInstanceId);
        oWorkflowComponent.setIsDraft(false);
        oWorkflowComponent.initWorkflow().then(
          function () {
            _control.setComponent(oWorkflowComponent);
            _parentControl.setBusy(false);
          }
        );
        this.oWorkflowComponent = oWorkflowComponent;
        try {
          var embeddedComponent = this.oWorkflowComponent.getRootControl().getContent()[0].getContent()[1];
          embeddedComponent.attachComponentCreated(function (oEvent) {
            var steps = oEvent.getParameter("component").getRootControl().getContent()[0].getItems();
            for (var i = 0; i < steps.length; i++) {
              steps[i].setType("Inactive");
            }
            let columns = oEvent.getParameter("component").getRootControl().getContent()[0].getColumns();
            columns.forEach((column) => {
              if (column.sId.indexOf("columnProcessors") > -1) {
                column.mBindingInfos = {};
              }
            });
            for (var j = 0; j < columns.length; j++) {
              if (
                columns[j].sId.indexOf("columnDeadline") > -1 ||
                columns[j].sId.indexOf("columnProcessors") > -1 ||
                columns[j].sId.indexOf("columnFirstProperty") > -1
              ) {
                columns[j].setVisible(false);
              }
            }
          });
        } catch (e) {
          _parentControl.setBusy(false);
        }
      }.bind(this)
    );
  }
},

You can find the parameters used in the function:

workflowInstanceId: Workflow instance ID , which is the document number like PO or PR number
scenarioID: Workflow scenario ID
ID: ComponentContainer ID
parentControlId: ObjectPageSection ID

After the embeddedComponent created, I try to fetch the workflow step list to hide columns and set the line item as inactive to avoid the line item navigation.  

 

By the above code, you can implement the Workflow Steps component in your custom free-styled Fiori app. 

Thanks,

Daniel
